3 different ways to localize your software

The process of localizing your software can be approached in three different ways:

Each approach has its own advantages and challenges. Choosing the right one largely depends on your projectâ€™s specific requirements and goals.

Waterfall localization takes place at a specific time in the software development cycleâ€“either at the very end (a post-release method) or during a specific period (the string freeze method).

Once the translated text is completed by the service provider, the software strings are manually uploaded back into the application for merging and publishing.

Agile localization syncs the localization process with the development process so that they are both operating simultaneously. New and modified strings are automatically detected and delivered whenever they are ready for merging and publishing.

Continuous localization is a step closer to making localization automated and seamless. While similar to agile, it fully integrates with the CI/CD method that companies use to frequently deliver software to customers.

Hereâ€™s the main difference, according to Miguel Sepulveda, Global Localization Manager at King:

â€œIn continuous localization, the content is always ready for a release. In agile localization, the content is not always ready to be releasedâ€“we need to wait until the sprint is completed.â€

Localizing your product can be a complex process, but if you keep these ten things in mind, it will become a lot easier.

â—Important note: This list is by no means comprehensiveâ€”these guidelines cover the basics to help you get set up.

Files with hard-coded localizable elements are a nightmare to handle, so youâ€™ll need to start by identifying all localizable text and creating a separate file for each language you need your software to be available in. This makes localization much easier to manage.

Use file formats like JSON, ARB, YAML, XLIFF, Android Resources, or Apple strings. The choice of format depends on the programming language or framework you use.

Keep your translation content clean by nesting strings to logically group each set of translations. Also, give each string a clear name that describes what it refers to and where it goes. For example, â€œPrimary CTAâ€ is more helpful than â€œAbcâ€.

After separating your files, you should start adding placeholders in your source code.

A placeholder allows for the insertion of dynamic content, such as a character, word, or string of characters.

The exact placeholder used varies based on the technology and coding language youâ€™re using. It tells your application that it should show the correct translation for the chosen language rather than a specific word. It looks something like this:

Along with using these placeholders, youâ€™ll also want to avoid concatenated strings because word order and syntax vary by language, and this can make parsing difficult.

Also, make sure that youâ€™re providing comments and context wherever you can so that your translators can understand where in the UI a given string appears and how, since this impacts the final meaning.

ðŸ’¡Pro tip: Use universal placeholders. This allows you to import/export your content in different file formats by converting placeholders into the format you need. Also, use a TMS that allows you to insert placeholders and, where possible, that the linguist can ideally work around.

3. Build in space as language length will change

Different languages take up different amounts of space on a page. So, you should always assume that text will grow or shrink.

For example, translating English to German can cause text to expand by up to 35%. English to Swedish, on the other hand, can contract text by up to 35%. If youâ€™re translating into Asian languages like Chinese, Japanese, or Korean, youâ€™ll also see vertical expansion from English.

Before you start to code, think through how different languages impact space during the design phase and save yourself headaches down the road.

Translating text first and then optimizing the UI in all languages will help you see how designs change based on the target language, helping you avoid design breaks and localization errors.

ðŸ’¡Pro tip: Build with flexibility in mind to ensure that your design can accommodate different translations. Check out how you can do that in Lokalise using the Figma, Sketch, and Adobe XD plugins.

Similarly, in the design phase, youâ€™ll want to make sure the images are inclusive and appropriate for various markets.

In the U.S., for example, the waving hand emoji is a common way to say hello or make your text appear friendly. But in Mainland China, that symbol means breaking off a friendship â€” the opposite of what you probably want to convey.

Youâ€™ll want to check all of your images and illustrations, not only for potential offensive trip-ups in other target markets, but also for meaningless or confusing symbols.

Understanding design preferences allows product teams to tailor their software to specific cultural and regional preferences.

Unsurprisingly, different markets have varying preferences for design styles and aesthetics.

For example, some markets may prefer minimalist designs that focus on white space and clean lines, while others may prefer more elaborate designs that incorporate more detailed information and visuals.

Example of the Starbucks website in Japan

In Japan, consumers often prefer more detailed and cluttered designs (Starbucks website on the right) that provide a wealth of information upfront, as it helps them make more informed purchasing decisions.

Western designs, on the other hand, tend to favor more minimalist and simplistic designs (Starbucks website on the left), which prioritize ease of use and readability.

Knowing how design differs from one new market to another, helps software localization teams create designs that are more appealing to local users.

Thinking about language is a great first step, but as you expand into more international markets, locale becomes more important.

Some languages may be similar, but that doesnâ€™t mean the culture is the same. Even in English, words, phrases, and spellings may be different if youâ€™re in the United States, Canada, the U.K, and Australia.

Think about this scenario: you specify â€œfrâ€ for French as your language code but donâ€™t take into consideration regional differences between francophone countries. What if you want to display different content to customers in Canada and Belgium?

All of these locales will have slightly different ways of speaking, different cultural expressions, and different ways of approaching your product. This is why you need to combine globalization and localization to engage your target audience.

In terms of terminology management, a glossary and style guide are key components of the language assets that you need to build to ensure your messaging and brand stay consistent across every market.

Thatâ€™s how you build consistent brand awareness. Creating a style guide and maintaining a glossary allows your linguists to work fast while maintaining quality.

Developers should make sure that all text is properly defined and labeled in a way that makes sense for those who translate it. This means including information about where and how a string appears in the user interface, as well as what it does.

Providing this contextual information can help translators understand the nuances of each language more quickly and accurately, which leads to better quality of translated content.

For example, if you have a string that reads â€œcancel,â€ knowing whether this refers to canceling an order or canceling an appointment will make all the difference in terms of accuracy.

And rememberâ€“nuances in language may not be obvious from a single word alone.

Translation memory is a database that stores previous translations and can be used to save time and money. For example, if you have a string that reads â€œThank you,â€ translation memory can detect if the same string has been previously translated and suggest the same translation. This can save time and money by eliminating the need to re-translate the same string.

What is software localization?

Software localization is the process of adapting software to meet the language, cultural, and functional needs of specific regions. This includes translating text, customizing interfaces, and adjusting features to ensure the software feels intuitive for local users.

Why is software localization important?

Software localization is crucial for businesses expanding globally. It helps create software that resonates with diverse audiences, improving user satisfaction, driving adoption, and increasing retention.

What are the challenges of software localization?

Challenges of software localization include managing cultural differences, handling technical complexities, working within budget and time constraints, and maintaining consistency across multiple language versions. Strong collaboration is important to overcoming these obstacles.

As businesses expand their reach to global markets, the need for effective localization becomes increasingly crucial. JSON, a lightweight data-interchange format, is ubiquitous in modern applications, making it a critical target for localization efforts. However, localizing JSON data can be challenging due to its dynamic nature and the complexity of translation processes. This guide will delve into ten essential tips for mastering JSON localization, empowering developers and linguists to create high-quality localized JSON files that resonate with global audiences.

Tip #1: Plan and Organize Your JSON Files for Localization

Effective localization of JSON files requires careful planning and organization to ensure that the translation process is efficient and accurate. Here are some key aspects to consider:
â€¢ Separate files for each language: Instead of having a single JSON file with all translations mixed together, create separate files for each language or language group. This makes it easy for translators to find the text they need to translate without getting overwhelmed by a large, monolithic file.

Example: Create folders for each language (en, fr, es) and place the JSON files for corresponding languages within those folders.
â€¢ Consistent naming conventions: Use clear and consistent naming conventions for your translation keys and values. Avoid using cryptic abbreviations or overly complex structures that might hinder translatorsâ€™ understanding.

Example: For a button label, use a naming convention like or instead of something like or .
â€¢ Handling large JSON files: When dealing with extensive JSON files, consider using file splitting techniques. Split the JSON data into smaller, more manageable chunks based on logical sections or data types. This makes it easier to navigate, translate, and merge translated segments.

Example: Split a large JSON file containing user profiles into individual files for each profile property (name, email, address, etc.).
â€¢ Managing dynamic data: When translating JSON files that incorporate dynamic data, use placeholders or templates to indicate where dynamic values should be inserted. This allows translators to focus on the core translation without worrying about specific data values.

Example: Instead of hardcoding a product name, use a placeholder like and let the translator insert the actual product name.
â€¢ Maintaining consistency across languages: As you translate JSON files for multiple languages, ensure consistency in terminology, formatting, and styling. Use style guides or style sheets to standardize the look and feel of translated texts.

Example: Define a style guide for font styles, spacing, and capitalization to maintain uniformity across translated versions.
â€¢ Utilize JSON localization tools: Leverage specialized JSON localization tools or plugins that automate tasks like extracting translatable text, merging translations, and checking for inconsistencies.

Example: Use tools like i18next, JSON Localization Library, or Localization Suite to streamline the localization process.
â€¢ Integrate with development workflow: Integrate localization into your development workflow to automate translation tasks and ensure seamless integration of translated files into your codebase.

Example: Use automated tools to extract translatable text from JSON files during builds or commits and integrate translated files into the development process.
â€¢ Establish quality assurance checks: Implement rigorous quality assurance processes to ensure the accuracy, consistency, and cultural appropriateness of translated JSON files.

Example: Conduct regular review sessions, involve native speakers, and use automated testing tools to validate translations.

Tip #2: Use Standard JSON Structures for Better Translation

Effective JSON localization requires the use of standard and consistent JSON structures to ensure that translators can easily understand and translate the data. This involves adhering to established conventions for array and object notation, making it easier for translators to grasp the data structure and provide accurate translations.
â€¢ Array Notation for Repetitive Data: Use array notation to represent groups of similar data elements. This allows translators to handle multiple translations for a single data type in a consistent manner.

Example: To translate a list of product names, use an array of objects for each language:
â€¢ Nested Objects for Hierarchical Data: Use nested objects to represent hierarchical data structures. This allows translators to translate each level of the hierarchy independently while maintaining context.

Example: To translate a user profile with multiple attributes, use nested objects for each attribute:
â€¢ Mapping Complex Data Structures: When dealing with complex data structures, it may be challenging to map the JSON structure to the translation format. Use tools or libraries specifically designed for JSON localization to handle complex data types and provide translators with clear instructions.
â€¢ Leveraging Placeholders for Variable Data: When translating JSON data that incorporates dynamic variables, use placeholders or templates to indicate where specific values should be inserted. This ensures that translators focus on the core translation without dealing with specific data values.
â€¢ Maintaining Translation Context: Ensure that the translation context is clear and consistent across different levels of the JSON data structure. Use descriptive names for objects and properties to provide translators with a clear understanding of the data.
â€¢ Embracing Automation: Leverage automation tools to streamline the translation process, such as extracting translatable text, merging translations, and checking for consistency. This frees up translators to focus on higher-level tasks and ensures accuracy.
â€¢ Establishing QA Processes: Implement rigorous quality assurance (QA) procedures to ensure the accuracy, consistency, and cultural appropriateness of translated JSON files. This involves involving native speakers, reviewing translations for errors, and conducting testing with target audiences.

By adopting standard JSON structures, utilizing automation tools, and implementing robust QA processes, developers and translators can collaborate effectively to produce high-quality localized JSON files that meet the needs of global audiences.
